metadata.title: Synthesis of tertiary <ce:italic>N,N</ce:italic>-dimethylbenzylamine via reductive amination of benzaldehyde with <ce:italic>N,N</ce:italic>-dimethylformamide over SnO<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> catalyst

Synthesis of tertiary N,N-dimethylbenzylamine via reductive amination of benzaldehyde with N,N-dimethylformamide over SnO2 catalyst Nobutaka Yamanaka Writing – original draft Visualization Validation Resources Project administration Methodology Investigation Funding acquisition Formal analysis Conceptualization ⁎ Koji Nishi Writing – review & editing Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Kenji Yasunaga Writing – review & editing Data curation Hiroshi Yamada Writing – review & editing Data curation Department of Applied Chemistry, National Defense Academy, 1-10-20 Hashirimizu, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-8686, Japan Department of Applied Chemistry National Defense Academy 1-10-20 Hashirimizu Yokosuka Kanagawa 239-8686 Japan Department of Applied Chemistry, National Defense Academy, 1-10-20 Hashirimizu, Yokosuka, Kanagawa 239-8686, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Tertiary amines, including N,N-dimethylbenzylamine (DMBA), are ubiquitous and valuable compounds in synthetic chemistry. DMBA is synthesized via the reductive amination of benzaldehyde (BA) with N,N-dimethylformamide as a secondary amine source, reductant, and solvent over Lewis acid catalysts. In this work, various metal oxides were applied for the reductive amination as heterogeneous Lewis acid catalysts. SnO2 was found to be the most effective Lewis acid catalyst, and under optimized reaction conditions, DMBA was synthesized in an excellent yield of 91.7 % at a BA conversion of 98.6 % (N2 pressure, 0.4 MPa; reaction temperature, 443 K; reaction time, 6 h). The most effective metal oxide catalyst was reusable at least three times for reductive amination without significant loss of its catalytic performance. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Tertiary N,N-dimethylbenzylamine Benzaldehyde N,N-Dimethylformamide Reductive amination Heterogeneous Lewis acid catalyst SnO2 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Amines are an important class of compounds in organic synthesis and the chemical industry [1–5]. Tertiary amines are particularly important because they are key structural motifs found in naturally occurring biologically active products, such as alkaloids, and synthetic products such as pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and functional materials [6,7]. They have also been used as ligands in organometallic complexes, organocatalysts in organic synthesis, modifiers for reversed phase chromatography, and buffers in the sequential analysis of proteins and peptides [7,8]. One method for synthesizing tertiary amines represents the nucleophilic substitution of alkyl halides with secondary amines in the presence of stoichiometric amounts of bases [9,10]. However, the serious drawback of this method is that it requires toxic alkyl halides and bases, which have a negative impact on the environment. Therefore, the reductive amination of carbonyl compounds with secondary amines is a more sustainable method compared with the nucleophilic substitution reaction because it does not require any toxic reagents. The reductive amination of carbonyl compounds comprises two steps: the condensation of carbonyl compounds with secondary amines to generate the corresponding iminium cation intermediates, followed by their reduction to the target tertiary amine products [11,12]. In reductive amination, H2 gas is frequently used as a reducing agent because it is low-priced, environmentally friendly, and produces only water as a byproduct [13–15]. However, H2 gas is flammable, and its use poses an explosive risk [16,17]. Thus, reducing agents with a lower safety risk during handling (e.g., formic acid) should be employed [18–20]. L. Yang et al. recently synthesized tertiary amines via the reductive amination of carbonyl compounds with N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) as a secondary amine source, reductant, and solvent over homogeneous Lewis acid catalysts [8]. The first step is proposed to be the homogeneous Lewis acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of DMF to produce dimethylamine and formic acid as a secondary amine and reducing agent, respectively. The research group used various homogeneous Lewis acid catalysts for the reductive amination of 2-napthaldehyde with DMF. Al, Co, Cu, Zn, and Sn-based homogeneous catalysts were found to be highly effective for the synthesis of the corresponding tertiary amine. However, homogeneous catalysts have the disadvantage of being difficult to separate from the reaction mixture for reuse, which can be overcome by using heterogeneous catalysts [10,21]. Therefore, heterogeneous Lewis acid catalysts that are highly effective for the synthesis of tertiary amines via the reductive amination of carbonyl compounds with DMF should be found. Metal oxides find applications in catalysis due to coordinatively unsaturated metal cations acting as Lewis acid sites on their surfaces, thereby exhibiting Lewis acidity [22–26]. In this work, we used the above-mentioned transition metal-based oxides (i.e., Al2O3, CoO, Co3O4, Cu2O, CuO, ZnO, SnO, and SnO2) as heterogeneous Lewis acid catalysts for the reductive amination of benzaldehyde (BA) with DMF to synthesize the corresponding tertiary amine N,N-dimethylbenzylamine (DMBA) (Scheme 1 ). After optimizing the reaction conditions using the most effective metal oxide catalyst, we investigated its reusability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Al2O3, CoO, Cu2O, CuO, ZnO, SnO, SnO2, p-xylene, BA, and DMF were purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Ind., Ltd. Co3O4 and DMBA were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd. All organic chemicals were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured at 77 K using a Belsorp Max after removing physisorbed gases by degassing the metal oxides at 423 K for 2 h. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation was used to calculate the specific surface areas. Pyridine temperature-programmed desorption (Py-TPD) studies were performed on a BELCAT-A instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector to determine the number and strength of the acid sites on the metal oxides. The samples were pretreated in a He flow at 423 K for 1 h, cooled to 373 K, and then saturated with pyridine vapors by passing a He flow through a saturator filled with liquid pyridine for 0.5 h. The physically adsorbed pyridine was then removed in a He flow at the same temperature for 0.25 h. The temperature was then increased to 1073 K at a rate of 10 K min-1. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD; D8 ADVANCE; Bruker) was carried out at 40 kV and 40 mA using CuK α radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm), and the crystal structures were identified using the Crystallography Open Database (COD) [27]. Fresh and spent SnO2 were scanned at a step width of 0.02° and a speed of 5° min−1 over the range 20° ≤ 2θ ≤ 80°. 2.3 Typical experimental procedures The reductive amination of BA with DMF over the metal oxide catalysts was carried out in a high-pressure autoclave with a magnetic stirrer, a pressure gauge, and an automatic temperature controller. In a typical procedure, SnO2 (50 mg), p-xylene (0.30 mmol) as an internal standard material, H2O (100 mg), BA (1.0 mmol), and DMF (4.0 mL) were charged into the autoclave. After sealing, the autoclave was purged with N2 to remove the air and maintained at 1.0 MPa at room temperature. The autoclave was placed in a preheated oil bath at 423 K for 24 h. After completion of the reaction, the autoclave was removed from the oil bath and rapidly cooled in a water bath to stop the reaction. The autoclave was then placed in the water bath for at least 0.5 h until the catalyst settled to the bottom of the autoclave [28]. The remaining N2 was then discharged, and the supernatant solution was analyzed using a gas chromatography (Nexis GC-2030; Shimadzu) with a flame ionization detector equipped with a capillary column (Rxi-5 ms, 30 m × 0.25 mm). The conversion of BA and the yield of the target product DMBA were calculated using the internal standard method. 3 Results and discussion Various metal oxides (i.e., Al2O3, CoO, Co3O4, Cu2O, CuO, ZnO, SnO, and SnO2) were applied to the reductive amination of BA with DMF as heterogeneous Lewis acid catalysts under N2 1.0 MPa at 423 K for 24 h. The results are shown in Table 1 . Reductive amination proceeded in all the metal oxides, resulting in the formation of DMBA. Among the metal oxides, SnO2 showed the highest catalytic performance and synthesized DMBA in an excellent yield of 94.4 % at a BA conversion of 99.6 % (Table 1, entry 1). The order of the catalytic activity of the metal oxides was SnO2 > SnO > ZnO > CoO > Al2O3 > Co3O4 > CuO > Cu2O. We compared the experimental results obtained from the BET and Py-TPD analyses to elucidate the factors influencing the catalytic activities. The order of the specific surface area and number of acid sites of the metal oxides did not correlate with the catalytic activity (Table S1). In addition, there was no clear correlation between the catalytic activity of the metal oxides and their acid strength (Fig. S1). Because S. Wang et al. demonstrated that the crystal structure has a significant impact on catalytic activity for reductive amination, the crystal structures of the metal oxides were compared with their catalytic activities; however, no correlation was observed (Table S1) [29]. Finally, the metal oxide catalytic activities were compared with various chemical properties (i.e., electronegativity, Lewis acid strength, acidity scale, and electrophilicity) obtained from the literature (Tables S2 and S3 and Fig. S2). However, no correlation was obtained. In this work, we were unable to elucidate the factors influencing the catalytic activity of the metal oxides for reductive amination. However, we did determine the optimized reaction conditions for the reductive amination of BA with DMF over the most effective catalyst, SnO2. The effect of the amount of H2O was investigated by varying the amount of H2O from 100 to 260 mg. Here, a shorter reaction time of 6 h was selected to evaluate the initial activity of SnO2 while keeping the other reaction parameters constant. The results are shown in Table 2 . 100 mg H2O showed a BA conversion of 26.0 % and a DMBA yield of 20.4 % (Table 2, entry 1). The catalytic performance of SnO2 was gradually enhanced by increasing the amount of H2O added (Table 2, entries 1–3). Using 180 mg H2O showed a BA conversion of 51.4 % and a DMBA yield of 42.9 % (Table 2, entry 3). Although more H2O was added to further enhance the catalytic performance of SnO2, the catalytic performance remained unchanged (Table 2, entries 4 and 5). Therefore, 180 mg H2O was found to be optimal for further experiments. The effect of the volume of DMF was investigated using around 4.0 mL DMF. The results are shown in Table 3 . When the reductive amination of BA with DMF over SnO2 was carried out using <4.0 mL DMF, the BA conversion and DMBA yield significantly dropped to 37.4 % and 32.6 %, respectively (Table 3, entry 1). When >4.0 mL DMF was used, the BA conversion and DMBA yield were similar to those obtained with a 4.0 mL DMF volume (Table 3, entries 2–4). Therefore, a DMF volume of 4.0 mL was optimal for further experiments. The effect of the reaction temperature ranging from 423 to 463 K was investigated. The results are shown in Table 4 . An increase in the reaction temperature was found to have a significant positive impact on the BA conversion and DMBA yield. While DMBA was formed in 42.9 % yield at 423 K, the target product was synthesized in almost quantitative yields at a reaction temperature of 443 K or higher (Table 4, entries 1–3). Therefore, 443 K was selected as the optimum reaction temperature for further experiments. The effect of the N2 pressure was investigated by decreasing the N2 pressure from 1.0 to 0.2 MPa. To evaluate the initial activity of SnO2, the reductive amination of BA with DMF was carried out for a shorter reaction time of 3 h. The results are shown in Table 5 . A decrease in the N2 pressure to 0.4 MPa had little influence on the BA conversion (66.4 %) and DMBA yield (62.7 %) (Table 5, entries 1–4), and a further decrease in the N2 pressure to 0.2 MPa decreased the conversion and yield to 60.7 % and 53.8 %, respectively (Table 5, entry 5). Similar behavior has been reported in the literature [30,31]. Therefore, a N2 pressure of 0.4 MPa was selected as the optimum condition for further experiments. Finally, the effect of the reaction time was investigated, and the results are illustrated in Fig. 1 . At a reaction time of 1.5 h, the BA conversion and DMBA yield were 29.8 % and 26.3 %, respectively. The conversion and yield gradually increased with an increase in the reaction time, reaching 98.6 % and 91.7 %, respectively, after 6 h. Prolonging the reaction time to 7 h did not lead to an increase in the DMBA yield. Therefore, a reaction time of 6 h was found to be optimal. The catalytic performance of SnO2 for the reductive amination of BA with DMF was compared with that of Co@CeO2NC. As shown in Table S4, although SnO2 required a slightly higher reaction temperature than Co@CeO2NC, it synthesized the target product DMBA with a higher BA/catalyst ratio and a much shorter reaction time [32]. In addition, SnO2 has the advantage of being commercially available at low cost. Therefore, the catalytic system developed here significantly improves the synthesis of DMBA from BA and DMF in terms of cost and performance, thus providing an economical and effective route to the synthesis of tertiary amines. Finally, the SnO2 reusability test for the reductive amination of BA with DMF was carried out under the optimized reaction conditions (N2 pressure, 0.4 MPa; reaction temperature, 443 K; reaction time, 6 h). The results are illustrated in Fig. 2 . After completion of the reaction, the spent catalyst was separated from the reaction solution by centrifugation, washed with acetone, dried in a vacuum overnight, and reused for the next run under identical reaction conditions. After the first run, the BA conversion and DMBA yield were 97.5 % and 85.7 %, respectively. Similar conversion and yield were achieved in the second run. Although a slight decrease in the catalytic performance of SnO2 was observed in the third run, a sufficiently high DMBA yield of 75.0 % was obtained at a BA conversion of 86.0 % in the fourth run. Thus, it was concluded that SnO2 is reusable at least three times for the synthesis of DMBA via the reductive amination of BA with DMF. To disclose the reason for the deactivation of the catalyst, we decided to carry out the reductive amination using 94.8 mg of fresh catalyst. This catalyst weight was chosen because 100 mg of fresh SnO2 was used in the first run, but the weight of SnO2 recovered after the third run was 94.8 mg. When the reductive amination was carried out using 94.8 mg of fresh SnO2, the BA conversion and DMBA yield were 88.0 % and 78.8 %, respectively, comparable to those obtained in the fourth run (BA conversion 86.0 % and DMBA yield 75.0 %). The similar BA conversion and DMBA yield obtained using fresh and used SnO2 at the same weight suggest that the physicochemical properties of SnO2 before and after the reaction remained unchanged. Thus, it was concluded that the catalyst deactivation observed from the first to the fourth run was primarily due to the loss of the catalyst during the recycling process. 4 Conclusions In this work, we have demonstrated that SnO2 is an effective heterogeneous Lewis acid catalyst for the reductive amination of BA with DMF to the corresponding tertiary amine DMBA. The metal oxide catalyst synthesized the target tertiary amine product with an excellent yield of 91.7 % at a BA conversion of 98.6 % under the optimized reaction conditions (N2 pressure, 0.4 MPa; reaction temperature, 443 K; reaction time, 6 h). This catalytic performance is superior to that of a previously reported heterogeneous catalyst. SnO2 was found to be reusable at least three times without significant loss of its catalytic performance. These admirable reaction results make our developed protocol an attractive strategy for the synthesis of various tertiary amines and accelerate the utilization of metal oxides as Lewis acid catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Tertiary amines, including N,N-dimethylbenzylamine (DMBA), are ubiquitous and valuable compounds in synthetic chemistry. DMBA is synthesized via the reductive amination of benzaldehyde (BA) with N,N-dimethylformamide as a secondary amine source, reductant, and solvent over Lewis acid catalysts. In this work, various metal oxides were applied for the reductive amination as heterogeneous Lewis acid catalysts. SnO2 was found to be the most effective Lewis acid catalyst, and under optimized reaction conditions, DMBA was synthesized in an excellent yield of 91.7 % at a BA conversion of 98.6 % (N2 pressure, 0.4 MPa; reaction temperature, 443 K; reaction time, 6 h). The most effective metal oxide catalyst was reusable at least three times for reductive amination without significant loss of its catalytic performance.
coredata.prism:publisher: Elsevier B.V. All rights are reserved, including those for text and data mining, AI training, and similar technologies.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of tertiary N,N-dimethylbenzylamine via reductive amination of benzaldehyde with N,N-dimethylformamide over SnO2 catalyst
